resources.string: Angle of slope from horizontal plane
Angle of cable from horizontal plane

Hg is the vertical distance between the ground supporting the equipment and the vehicular center of gravity. The lower Hg is, the more stable the equipment anchor will be against overturning. For more details, see figure 1.

Cg is the lateral distance between the point of rotation (i.e. the bottom of an embedded blade, the toe of the vehicle, etc.) and the center of gravity for the equipment. Bear in mind that the center of gravity for equipment is dependent on attachments, location of appendages (excavator boom, etc.) and track setup, all of which may vary. Be sure to be conservative in choice of this location.
Tg is the ultimate anchor capacity. This delimiting force marks the tension in the anchor cable that will cause the equipment anchor to move and become unstable.
Db is the embedment depth of the equipment. This value is representative of the depth below the depending on the scenario.
wb is the width of the blade, shovel or equipment that is in contact with the adjacent, resisting soil of embedment.
Wv is the weight of the equipment, measured as a force. The vehicular weight is located at a distance from the point of rotation, labeled as Cg.
La is the lateral distance between the point of rotation (i.e. the bottom of an embedded blade, the toe of the vehicle, etc.) and the point at which an anchor is attached.
Ha is the vertical distance between the ground supporting the equipment and the anchor attachment point. The lower Ha is, the more stable the equipment anchor will be against overturning.
Phi is the angle of internal friction for soil, which governs soil strength and resistance. This value should be attained from competent field testing and the judgment of a licensed engineer.

C is soil cohesion. Cohesion defines the non-stress dependent shear strength of soil and should be used with caution. Typically, cohesion occurs in stiff, over-consolidated clays or cemented native soils. Cohesion should be neglected if the designer is unsure of its presence.
Ws is the unit weight of the soil. This value represents the approximate bulk weight in a certain volume of soil.
